channel.title: Animation and Models
channel.description:
Hi, I've adapted the RS model viewer to export metasequoia files(for editing) and i want to try to adapt the viewer to display character animation, which is what i'm stuck on.
Can anyone help with the following :-
Does anyone know which class, in the 317 deob, deals with animation? Does anyone know where the animation files are stored? server or client cache? Does anyone have an animation file? (for anything!)
I'd write an RS model exporter, but there's no point in creating custom character models if you can't animate them!
MrPotatoHead

item.title: Animation and Models
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

the only thing thats really changing is the size of the header from what im seeing, please not i just did a quick renaming in notepad. there is also two new values which i would assume dont effect the basic structure. ill take a further look into it later.
client: 474

New header notice the increase in size

	class37_sub11.anInt2055 = is.length - 23;
	int vertex = readShort(61);
	int faces = readShort(-126);
	int i_134_ = readRawByte(122);
	int i_135_ = readRawByte(124);
	int i_136_ = readRawByte(122);
	int i_137_ = readRawByte(118);
	int i_138_ = readRawByte(125);
	int i_139_ = readRawByte(124);
	int i_140_ = readRawByte(124);
	int i_141_ = readShort(-128);
	int i_142_ = readShort(44);
	int i_143_ = readShort(-122);
	int i_144_ = readShort(72);
	int i_145_ = readShort(92);

old header

	class37_sub11.anInt2055 = is.length - 18;
	int numVertices = readShort(117);
	int numTriangles = readShort(-124);
	int numTexTriangles = readRawByte(122);
	int k = readRawByte(126);
	int l = readRawByte(123);
	int i1 = readRawByte(124);
	int j1 = readRawByte(125);
	int k1 = readRawByte(125);
	int l1 = readShort(26);
	int i2 = readShort(109);
	int j2 = readShort(-119);
	int k2 = readShort(-123);
	int offset = 0;

317 old header

        ByteStream stream = new ByteStream(abyte0);
        stream.setCaret(abyte0.length - 18);
        ModelHeader header = new ModelHeader();
        header.payload = abyte0;
        header.numVertices = stream.readShort();
        header.numTriangles = stream.readShort();
        header.numTexTriangles = stream.readRawByte();
        int k = stream.readRawByte();
        int l = stream.readRawByte();
        int i1 = stream.readRawByte();
        int j1 = stream.readRawByte();
        int k1 = stream.readRawByte();
        int l1 = stream.readShort();
        int i2 = stream.readShort();
        int j2 = stream.readShort();
        int k2 = stream.readShort();
        int l2 = 0;
        header.dirOffset = l2;

Read full topic

item.title: Animation and Models
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

You’re both wrong…and right…how that happen?

There are 2 headers.
It doesn’t make sense to make 2 loaders so they must use one loader, which must be different from the 317.
The data chunks contain the same data, cept they have been moved around, and there’s probably more data chunks.

see for yourself.

after 20 mins model scanning…

g = good
m = malformed
crashhhhh = won't load at all

142.mdl = model type 2 - g
143.mdl = model type 2 -m
144.mdl = model type 2 -m
145.mdl = model type 2 -m
1621.mdl = model type 2 - crashhhhh

good....
11112.mdl = model type 2
12393.mdl = model type 2
12394.mdl = model type 2
12736.mdl = model type 2
12737.mdl = model type 2


15550.mdl = model type 2 - g

15552.mdl = model type 2 - m

item.title: Animation and Models
item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:39, topic:150449”][quote author=sh!ft link=topic=206010.msg1859651#msg1859651 date=1193913221]

it is what he has assumed to be their in-house names, that is how they appear inside the password applet, which is (or wasnt) obfuscated

Yup. Jagex’s password change applet is not obfuscated thus giving us a portal into Jagex’s way of thinking, however bleak.

It’s obfuscated already, can someone please post the unobfuscated one?
[/quote]No, it’s not obfuscated dumbshit. Try learning what obfuscation means in the field of computer science.

Lol. The new version of the password changer is servlet based. It’s not only unobfuscated, its not even an applet. lolz
[/quote][quote author=sh!ft link=topic=206010.msg1859633#msg1859633 date=1193911866]

P.S. If anyone can upload and PM me a link to a newer format model, it’d be interesting to look at, and i’d be very grateful…

I don’t believe the model format has changed between old and new engine clients. Therefore sh!ft must mean that jagex uses both formats in both clients.

To the contrary, there is two DISTINCT formats. However, it is true that the second format is widely unused, for now.

This community seems to adore regression. No community projects? No community documentation? No one stops frank_ and other counter productive members from spamming up the place with pointless comments and general insults, instead they’re promoted to “Community Member.” It’s more like bottom feeding, cleaning up what scraps the knowledgeable wipe off their table.

    private model(byte[] file) {
        if (file[file.length - 1] == -1 && file[file.length - 2] == -1)
            unpack_small(file);
        else
            unpack_large(file);
    }

That’s the sieve. Two clear formats. Oh, and by the way, you can use that to hook the model class.

Edit: Somehow, I feel warranted in adding this -> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sieve

your mistaken, there is only 1 model format that they load from. its the one that calls upon loading of the header.

Wrong again, there’s two model formats and they are both used, it’s why half your object models don’t load properly in bentski’s model viewer, but I guess you wouldn’t notice it, you couldn’t code it.

Bentski only supports the main format.

actually its the header that is now two formats not how the model data is read.

as for bentski’s model viewer it still loads them all fine. the fact is the only error is that 1 it cant change the models color since thats stored in the definition file of either the item npc obj, and it cannot load textures since its not saved in the model file.[/quote]

If you say so woman…

Read full topic

To the contrary, there is two DISTINCT formats. However, it is true that the second format is widely unused, for now.

This community seems to adore regression. No community projects? No community documentation? No one stops frank_ and other counter productive members from spamming up the place with pointless comments and general insults, instead they’re promoted to “Community Member.” It’s more like bottom feeding, cleaning up what scraps the knowledgeable wipe off their table.

    private model(byte[] file) {
        if (file[file.length - 1] == -1 && file[file.length - 2] == -1)
            unpack_small(file);
        else
            unpack_large(file);
    }

That’s the sieve. Two clear formats. Oh, and by the way, you can use that to hook the model class.

Edit: Somehow, I feel warranted in adding this -> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sieve

your mistaken, there is only 1 model format that they load from. its the one that calls upon loading of the header.
[/quote]

Wrong again, there’s two model formats and they are both used, it’s why half your object models don’t load properly in bentski’s model viewer, but I guess you wouldn’t notice it, you couldn’t code it.

Bentski only supports the main format.[/quote]
actually its the header that is now two formats not how the model data is read.

as for bentski’s model viewer it still loads them all fine. the fact is the only error is that 1 it cant change the models color since thats stored in the definition file of either the item npc obj, and it cannot load textures since its not saved in the model file.

I mistook login applet for the password changer applet itself, my bad. Still would be nice if someone could post the old password changer applet.
And Silver Lining i reported you.

item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:31, topic:150449”][quote author=sh!ft link=topic=206010.msg1847554#msg1847554 date=1193487896]

P.S. If anyone can upload and PM me a link to a newer format model, it’d be interesting to look at, and i’d be very grateful…

I don’t believe the model format has changed between old and new engine clients. Therefore sh!ft must mean that jagex uses both formats in both clients.

To the contrary, there is two DISTINCT formats. However, it is true that the second format is widely unused, for now.

This community seems to adore regression. No community projects? No community documentation? No one stops frank_ and other counter productive members from spamming up the place with pointless comments and general insults, instead they’re promoted to “Community Member.” It’s more like bottom feeding, cleaning up what scraps the knowledgeable wipe off their table.

    private model(byte[] file) {
        if (file[file.length - 1] == -1 && file[file.length - 2] == -1)
            unpack_small(file);
        else
            unpack_large(file);
    }

That’s the sieve. Two clear formats. Oh, and by the way, you can use that to hook the model class.

Edit: Somehow, I feel warranted in adding this -> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sieve

[/quote]
your mistaken, there is only 1 model format that they load from. its the one that calls upon loading of the header.[/quote]

Wrong again, there’s two model formats and they are both used, it’s why half your object models don’t load properly in bentski’s model viewer, but I guess you wouldn’t notice it, you couldn’t code it.

Bentski only supports the main format.

item.title: Animation and Models
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

My bad - you can’t read beyond it, keep forgetting that the triangle color data is even there…ooops

Can’t find that if statement in the 317, but if you tell me it’s in the 317 i’ll have another look - i’ll even put my glasses on. I think it isn’t in the 317.

The actual model files (28704-28720) that end in FFFF are talking heads like the 0.dat, the footer has an extra byte flag at the beginning, one in the middle and 4 (bytes) at the end (including the FFFF).
You can hexedit the extra values out to view them in rsmv if you don’t have delphi.
Apart from those flags and maybe some animation data we don’t yet understand, it’s still the same file format!!!

It’s just jagex being gay. :eek:

They could have at least used bits for the load flags and triangle type data, or maybe taken the 12 redundant textured triangles out of the normal tree model

BAH…

Read full topic

item.title: Animation and Models
item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

[quote=“MrPotatoHead, post:25, topic:150449”]Darn, i completely overlooked that IF statement, thanks for pointing it out.
If you read the ‘large’ file reader method you’ll notice that animation data (3 sets of data) is read using NumTri as a counter, even though the data maybe NumVert or less in length. On very small models there is the possibilty of reading past the end of the file, so i guess the second ‘small’ format is used to prevent crashes…i’ll check.

Shift - You’ll have to learn how much fun squeazing lemons can be.

MrPotatoHead - Aaaarrrrgh!!! MY EYES!!![/quote]

Not really. “NumTri” is “g3”. Etc, etc. I don’t see how it would read beyond it? Maybe I’m just blind from all the lemon squeezing <3. Wait, that’s onions, shit. I use jagex’s in house names for packet and packetcypher.

Read full topic
